Tesla's real-world AI might prove more valuable than its LLM counterparts. 

The AI of FSD and Optimus are (will be) the sameâ€” vision-based AI based on real-world data. Lots of data, data beyond anything ever conceivably training into a LLM.

The FSD and Optimus AI architectures will be "one stack"â€” one unified model. And inference at the edge will prove to be more powerful than data center centralization. 

These are photon processing machines.

I learned today that the impact of scaling RL compute on LLM performance follows the same behavior as the biological effect of increasing the dose of a drug! 

Specifically,  the sigmoidal scaling curve we fit in the "Art of Scaling RL" to predict RL performance when scaling compute is same as the E_max model, that predicts the effect a drug can have based on its dose. Emax model is based on the Hill equation,  widely used in biochemistry and pharmacology.

Here's the equivalence between the E_max model and RL compute scaling curve:
- Drug concentration ~= Compute (C)
- Drug response (E) ~= RL Performance (R_c - R_0)
- Max Drug Effect (E_max) ~=  Asymptote RL performance (A - R0)
- Hill coefficient (n) ~= RL Compute efficiency (B)
- Concentration for 50% E_Max  (EC_50)  = Compute for 50% perf gain (C_mid)

How did I learn about this? @brandfonbrener reached out to to a statistics professor at MIT (Phillipe Rigollet) and he pointed us towards this connection!

What this means practically? Because the Emax model is widely-used in other fields of science, there are numerous ways to fit the coefficients in the scaling curve and this might be much better than the naive way to fit scaling coefficients we used in our work. 

References:
- Art of Scaling RL: x.com/Devvrit_Khatriâ€¦
- E_max model: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hill_equaâ€¦

*ANTHROPIC IN TALKS FOR GOOGLE CLOUD DEAL WORTH TENS OF BILLIONS

$GOOGL

"Anthropic is in discussions with $GOOGL about a deal for additional computing power valued in the high tens of billions. The deal will allow Anthropic to use $GOOGL's TPUs."

I said it multiple times, $GOOGL's TPUs are the most underappreciated asset in the market right now. All of $GOOGL's internal AI workloads, including their frontier LLM Gemini, already run and have been trained on TPUs.

$GOOGL is not going to sell TPUs as hardware, because the IP is too valuable and $GOOGL has internally perfected and optimized the whole stack for them. But they are going to sell additional GCP compute instances with TPUs.

Atlas is being positioned as a new interface for the web where ChatGPT doesnâ€™t live on a separate tab, but rather inside your browsing experience.

That means ChatGPT can:

Read the page youâ€™re on.

It basically turns every website into a potential conversation endpoint.

Read page content directly (not just summaries).

Even worse, if a competitorâ€™s page provides a more structured or factual explanation of what you offer, ChatGPTâ€™s in-browser agent may recommend them instead of you.

How Fingerprinting Improves Trust in Sentientâ€™s OML 1.0

@SentientAGI uses Fingerprinting to make sure every piece of data and model in the Open Meta Layer (OML 1.0) can be verified.

Fingerprinting works like a digital ID; it gives each dataset, model, or agent a unique mark that proves itâ€™s real and hasnâ€™t been changed. This helps keep the system transparent and reliable.

When agents share data through ROMA (Recursive Open Meta Agent) or search with ODP (Open Deep Search), Fingerprinting ensures what they find is original and verifiable.

Itâ€™s a simple but powerful layer of trust, helping Sentient build a transparent ecosystem where onchain data, decentralized storage, and verifiable intelligence all stay authentic and traceable.

How Fingerprinting Improves Trust in Sentientâ€™s OML 1.0

@SentientAGI uses Fingerprinting to make sure every piece of data and model in the Open Meta Layer (OML 1.0) can be verified.

Fingerprinting works like a digital ID; it gives each dataset, model, or agent a unique mark that proves itâ€™s real and hasnâ€™t been changed. This helps keep the system transparent and reliable.

When agents share data through ROMA (Recursive Open Meta Agent) or search with ODP (Open Deep Search), Fingerprinting ensures what they find is original and verifiable.

Itâ€™s a simple but powerful layer of trust, helping Sentient build a transparent ecosystem where onchain data, decentralized storage, and verifiable intelligence all stay authentic and traceable.

How Fingerprinting Improves Trust in Sentientâ€™s OML 1.0

@SentientAGI uses Fingerprinting to make sure every piece of data and model in the Open Meta Layer (OML 1.0) can be verified.

Fingerprinting works like a digital ID; it gives each dataset, model, or agent a unique mark that proves itâ€™s real and hasnâ€™t been changed. This helps keep the system transparent and reliable.

When agents share data through ROMA (Recursive Open Meta Agent) or search with ODP (Open Deep Search), Fingerprinting ensures what they find is original and verifiable.

Itâ€™s a simple but powerful layer of trust, helping Sentient build a transparent ecosystem where onchain data, decentralized storage, and verifiable intelligence all stay authentic and traceable.

Prompt

Why do LLM agents crack under pressure? We're turning those failures into concrete optimization targets.

MindGames is the new arena for deep social reasoning, stressing LLMs on three core modes:

> Hidden info co-op: Inferring private state from constrained signals.
> Adversarial bluffing: Where deception is optimal & lie detection matters.
> Coalition & Negotiation: Forming alliances, defecting when incentives flip, and replanning.

We log everything from actions to optional belief states to track not just wins, but truthfulness, betrayal frequency, and theory of mind proxies.

When incentives flip or plans get long, we see the brittle message drift and overaggression. Now, those errors are repeatable, auditable data.

#LLM #AIResearch #MultiAgent #MindGames

Wrote up my first impressions of ChatGPT Atlas, OpenAI's new browser - I remain unconvinced by the entire category of "browser agents", the security and privacy challenges still feel insurmountable to me
LATEST: OpenAI just launched its own browser, "ChatGPT Atlas."

OpenAI has announced its own browser, ChatGPT Atlas

It is currently available only on Mac

 pic.x.com/trOk2nPHcx

ChatGPT Atlas: my first impressions

I'm really trying to see the value in the AI browser, honestly. But so far, I don't see any added value, not even compared to Perplexity Comet.

But maybe that's because I'm not the target audience. For those who don't work with ChatGPT, Claude, or Gemini every day, every hour, it might be exciting to have a browser you can ask questions.

But all the features that have been implemented are ones I could already use in ChatGPT: ChatGPT Agent, summaries, follow-up questions.

The advertised features, such as having the agent do tasks for me, would probably take longer than if I just did the clicks myself, to be honest.

Again, for those who use ChatGPT or any AI on a daily basis, this browser will offer little added value. I think it is intended to appeal to those who have not yet come into daily contact with AI.

It is intended to lower the inhibition threshold and improve access to ChatGPT, similar to the integration of ChatGPT into WhatsApp or via phone call. For these people, it is certainly great to be able to ask questions on their daily news page.

Let's see if I can get better access to Atlas in the next few days.

But maybe I'm overlooking something and you see it completely differently. What is your impression? I would be really interested to know!

OpenAI has unveiled its new AI-powered browser â€” ChatGPT Atlas

Atlas lets users summon ChatGPT directly on any webpage. The bot can summarize text, compare products, analyze data, or assist with emails and calendars.

In agent mode, it can even make purchases, book tables, and automatically fill out forms.

The browser is already available for macOS, with Windows, iOS, and Android versions coming soon.
According to Reuters, ChatGPT Atlas will even be able to handle simple freelance tasks.

OpenAI is entering a crowded market: Google has integrated Gemini into Chrome, Microsoft added Copilot to Edge, and Perplexity recently launched its own browser, Comet AI.

OpenAI has just released ChatGPT Atlas an AI web browser that:

â€” Does tasks for you
â€” Summarizes webpages
â€” Acts on its own
â€” Can remember your web history

OpenAI introduced ChatGPT Atlas (codename Aura), a new web browser with ChatGPT built right in

- ChatGPT Atlas is based on Chromium, so Chrome extensions like AIPRM for ChatGPT and for Claude work with it, and you can import your passwords, bookmarks, and history from your current browser

- ChatGPT works anywhere on the web with a sidebar to help summarize pages and handle tasks, lets you write or edit text in any form field, and gives you search results organized into tabs for links, images, videos, and news via "super widget" tool (discovered previously)

- Browser memories (tool codename "kaur1br5" discovered previously) are optional and let ChatGPT remember things from sites you visit to help you later, like finding a page you read before, and you control what it remembers through settings where you can delete individual memories or wipe everything by clearing your history

- Your browsing data isn't used to train their models unless you turn that on yourself, you can use incognito mode to browse without ChatGPT watching, and parents can block browser memories and agent mode for their kids

- Agent mode is a preview feature for Plus, Pro, and Business users that lets ChatGPT open tabs and click through websites to do multi-step tasks for you like planning meals and adding groceries to your cart, and it asks permission before doing important stuff

- Agent mode has limits for safety - it can't download files, install extensions, access your computer files or other apps, see your passwords, or use autofill, and it pauses on banking sites to make sure you're watching what it does

- Sites that ChatGPT visits in agent mode don't show up in your browsing history, you can run it while logged out of your accounts for more privacy, and you can stop or take over anytime

- Available now on macOS for Free, Plus, Pro, and Go users worldwide, in beta for Business users and for Enterprise and Edu if admins allow it, with Windows, iOS, and Android versions coming soon

- New users who make Atlas their default browser get higher ChatGPT usage limits for 7 days, but the increase only applies when using ChatGPT within the Atlas browser and not on chatgpt[.]com, then limits go back to normal automatically

Congrats to @LangChainAI on raising a $125M Series B! 

3 years ago (a month before ChatGPT launched!), @hwchase17 released LangChain as a popular "get started" booster pack. It was the first LLM agent package to really take off. As the agent space matured and changed rapidly, the framework has gone through significant controversy and growing pains. Harrison listened to the hard feedback and persisted. 

Today the company maintains a trio of category leading products across the full agent engineering spectrum:
* LangChain (80M monthly downloads) for high-level agent development. Today's 1.0 release is written on top of LangGraph's runtime, bridging the rapid-start energy of O.G. LangChain with the low-level customization and control that developers need today
* LangGraph (12M monthly downloads) for low-level agent orchestration framework and runtime, used to power production agents at companies like @Uber @Klarna @LinkedIn and @jpmorgan
* LangSmith (traces growing 12x y-o-y) as a developer workbench for observability, evals, and deployment, used by companies such as @clay @Cloudflare @Replit @TrustVanta @Rippling @mercor_ai.
And lots more in development across memory, natural-language agent building, and more.

Congrats to @hwchase17 @ankush_gola11 @j_schottenstein on today's milestone. I admire your vision and resilience and am honored to be a part of your journey @sequoia

- Your browsing data isn't used to train their models unless you turn that on yourself, you can use incognito mode to browse without ChatGPT watching, and parents can block browser memories and agent mode for their kids

- Agent mode is a preview feature for Plus, Pro, and Business users that lets ChatGPT open tabs and click through websites to do multi-step tasks for you like planning meals and adding groceries to your cart, and it asks permission before doing important stuff

- Agent mode has limits for safety - it can't download files, install extensions, access your computer files or other apps, see your passwords, or use autofill, and it pauses on banking sites to make sure you're watching what it does

- Sites that ChatGPT visits in agent mode don't show up in your browsing history, you can run it while logged out of your accounts for more privacy, and you can stop or take over anytime

- Available now on macOS for Free, Plus, Pro, and Go users worldwide, in beta for Business users and for Enterprise and Edu if admins allow it, with Windows, iOS, and Android versions coming soon

- New users who make Atlas their default browser get higher ChatGPT usage limits for 7 days, but the increase only applies when using ChatGPT within the Atlas browser and not on chatgpt[.]com, then limits go back to normal automatically

Claude Desktop is now generally available.

New on Mac: Capture screenshots, click windows to share context, and press Caps Lock to talk to Claude aloud.

Congrats to @LangChainAI on raising a $125M Series B! 

3 years ago (a month before ChatGPT launched!), @hwchase17 released LangChain as a popular "get started" booster pack. It was the first LLM agent package to really take off. As the agent space matured and changed rapidly, the framework has gone through significant controversy and growing pains. Harrison listened to the hard feedback and persisted. 

Today the company maintains a trio of category leading products across the full agent engineering spectrum:
* LangChain (80M monthly downloads) for high-level agent development. Today's 1.0 release is written on top of LangGraph's runtime, bridging the rapid-start energy of O.G. LangChain with the low-level customization and control that developers need today
* LangGraph (12M monthly downloads) for low-level agent orchestration framework and runtime, used to power production agents at companies like @Uber @Klarna @LinkedIn and @jpmorgan
* LangSmith (traces growing 12x y-o-y) as a developer workbench for observability, evals, and deployment, used by companies such as @clay @Cloudflare @Replit @TrustVanta @Rippling @mercor_ai.
And lots more in development across memory, natural-language agent building, and more.

Congrats to @hwchase17 @ankush_gola11 @j_schottenstein on today's milestone. I admire your vision and resilience and am honored to be a part of your journey @sequoia

As weâ€™ve seen, @SentientAGI is more than just an AI project itâ€™s a fully open-source ecosystem built for scalable LLM research, infrastructure, and real-world products.

Here, models, agents, and data evolve together, continuously improving in a step-by-step, self-reinforcing loop.

Sentient moves beyond the traditional competition between AI models. Instead, it creates a new paradigm of collaboration: collective intelligence networks where agents can share knowledge, coordinate tasks, and learn from one another.

This approach accelerates AI innovation while keeping everything transparent, community-driven, and open for contribution.

With Sentient, the future of AI isnâ€™t just about building smarter models itâ€™s about building smarter communities of intelligence.

gSenti to all $SENT believers

BREAKING NEWS:

@OpenAI built a browser. It launches today and it's amazing.

We got our hands on it today @Every for early testing and here's our vibe check:

â€¢ ChatGPT built INTO the browser, not bolted onâ€”itâ€™s a sidebar on any webpage that can do read and write in any text field you have open

â€¢ Itâ€™s an agent that execute multi-step tasks autonomously (booking movie tickets, shopping for Bibles, drafting emails with calendar conflicts)

â€¢ It has a memory system tracks where you browse and what you doâ€”surfaces suggestions based on your context

â€¢ Available TODAY for Plus, Pro, AND Free tier users (MacOS only now, Windows/mobile coming)

â€¢ The closest comp is @diabrowser, but Atlas ships with agent mode that Dia hasn't launched yet

@OpenAI is clearly going for a full consumer play here. In our testing, Atlas feels less like learning something new than a browser that has caught up to how I already want to work with AI.

The AI browser wars are heating up.

Today weâ€™re excited to announce new funding for LangChain (at a $1.25B valuation) to allow us to build the platform for agent engineering.

LangChain started as a single Python package 3 years ago. Since then, weâ€™ve evolved into a comprehensive platform for agent engineering (LangGraph, LangSmith). Our tools now power AI teams like @Replit, @clay, @harvey, @TrustVanta, @Cloudflare, @Rippling, @Cisco, @Workday , and many more.

Over the past three years weâ€™ve iterated from LangChain to LangSmith to LangGraph. Our goal has always been to figure out what the agents of the future look like, and then build tools to help make them real.

While our journey is still just beginning, I also want to take this moment to reflect on the past three years and how the space (and our offerings) have evolved. I wrote some personal reflections here: blog.langchain.com/three-years-laâ€¦

We also share more about the funding that will power our future here: blog.langchain.com/series-b/?utm_â€¦ . Thank you to @IVP , @benchmark , @sequoia , @CapitalG , @SapphireVC , @AmplifyPartners  and others for their belief in us.

And what Iâ€™m most excited about today is that weâ€™re launching a number of new features and products: an insights agent in LangSmith, 1.0 releases of LangChain and LangGraph, and a no-code agent builder. Weâ€™ll talk a lot more about these throughout the week.

We are in the middle of a transformational technological shift, and are always looking for partners along the way. Whether you have feedback for us, want to work with us, or want to join us - please reach out!

Read more here about what this means for the future of building agents: blog.langchain.com/series-b/?utm_â€¦

BREAKING NEWS:

@OpenAI built a browser. It launches today and it's amazing.

We got our hands on it today @Every for early testing and here's our vibe check:

â€¢ ChatGPT built INTO the browser, not bolted onâ€”itâ€™s a sidebar on any webpage that can do read and write in any text field you have open

â€¢ Itâ€™s an agent that execute multi-step tasks autonomously (booking movie tickets, shopping for Bibles, drafting emails with calendar conflicts)

â€¢ It has a memory system tracks where you browse and what you doâ€”surfaces suggestions based on your context

â€¢ Available TODAY for Plus, Pro, AND Free tier users (MacOS only now, Windows/mobile coming)

â€¢ The closest comp is @diabrowser, but Atlas ships with agent mode that Dia hasn't launched yet

@OpenAI is clearly going for a full consumer play here. In our testing, Atlas feels less like learning something new than a browser that has caught up to how I already want to work with AI.

The AI browser wars are heating up.

Today weâ€™re excited to announce new funding for LangChain (at a $1.25B valuation) to allow us to build the platform for agent engineering.

LangChain started as a single Python package 3 years ago. Since then, weâ€™ve evolved into a comprehensive platform for agent engineering (LangGraph, LangSmith). Our tools now power AI teams like @Replit, @clay, @harvey, @TrustVanta, @Cloudflare, @Rippling, @Cisco, @Workday , and many more.

Over the past three years weâ€™ve iterated from LangChain to LangSmith to LangGraph. Our goal has always been to figure out what the agents of the future look like, and then build tools to help make them real.

While our journey is still just beginning, I also want to take this moment to reflect on the past three years and how the space (and our offerings) have evolved. I wrote some personal reflections here: blog.langchain.com/three-years-laâ€¦

We also share more about the funding that will power our future here: blog.langchain.com/series-b/?utm_â€¦ . Thank you to @IVP , @benchmark , @sequoia , @CapitalG , @SapphireVC , @AmplifyPartners  and others for their belief in us.

And what Iâ€™m most excited about today is that weâ€™re launching a number of new features and products: an insights agent in LangSmith, 1.0 releases of LangChain and LangGraph, and a no-code agent builder. Weâ€™ll talk a lot more about these throughout the week.

We are in the middle of a transformational technological shift, and are always looking for partners along the way. Whether you have feedback for us, want to work with us, or want to join us - please reach out!

We raised $125M to build the platform for agent engineering.

Thank you to our investors (@IVP, @sequoia, @benchmark, @AmplifyPartners, @SapphireVC, @CapitalG, and more) for their belief in us, and to our customers like @Replit, @clay, @TrustVanta, @Cloudflare, @Rippling, @Cisco, @Workday, and many more for their trust.

Read more here about what this means for the future of building agents: blog.langchain.com/series-b/?utm_â€¦

Crypto is finally learning how to move.

The @Gemini x @solana card turns staking and rewards into something you actually use. No more â€œfarm and forgetâ€.

Earning, spending, and compounding now happen in a single feedback loop.  

One where on chain value meet off chain utility. 

With auto staking and 4% SOL back, itâ€™s a concrete prototype for how digital assets can flow through real economies.

What happens when your wallet replaces your bank entirely?

A recent study showed that LLM traffic converts ~9x higher than traditional search.

It also highlighted some ways SEO Stuff (seo-stuff.com) has quietly been getting customers traffic + sales in 2025. 

Now that everything is out in the open, let's talk about it. 

But before we dive in...

If you want 3 unconfirmed cheat codes for landing in ChatGPT within the next ~30 or so days, just RT this + follow me + reply with "SEO Stuff ChatGPT Cheat Codes" and I'll DM them to you. 

You must do all 3 for the DM. 

Alright, let's get into it. 

A recent study from Lutz Finger (Forbes + Cornell) which I'll link to below found that when people use AI-driven interfaces like ChatGPT to discover products, they convert nearly NINE times better than traditional SEO traffic.

Thatâ€™s not a typo, by the way.

And it's not a future prediction. 

Itâ€™s what they literally saw in the research. 

It's also kind of why SEO Stuff's Gold Plan (seo-stuff.com/gold-plan-packâ€¦) went viral over the past couple of months.

Businesses are realizing the time to plant a flag in AI search is now because of how high-intent that traffic is. 

So let's get into the numbers. 

Finger and his team ran A/B tests using e-commerce sites that offered two search modes:

Traditional keyword-based search.

ChatGPT-style AI conversational search.

The difference was massive.

AI-driven sessions had 9x higher conversion rates.

Average query length jumped from 2â€“3 words to 23 words.

Sessions lasted 6+ minutes.

Shoppers said it â€œfelt like advice from a knowledgeable friend.â€

So what does that mean?

Well, it suggests people donâ€™t want lists of links anymore.

Rather, they want answers that sound like a conversation and theyâ€™re 9x more likely to buy when they get them.

LLMs are becoming the decision layer before purchase, and while traditional SEO brings users to your site, AI search pre-qualifies them before they ever click.

As noted in the Forbes piece, when someone asks ChatGPT:

â€œWhatâ€™s a compact camera for wildlife photography that fits in a carry-on?â€

Thatâ€™s not a casual query, itâ€™s an active purchase decision.

In these cases, being cited as the trusted answer is *almost* the new Page 1 ranking.

Not quite fully yet, but we are clearly trending in that direction. 

So what does this mean for brands? 

To show up in LLM responses, your content needs to be structured like something a model can understand and reuse. 

That includes:

Conversational formatting: Write like youâ€™re answering a question, not publishing a press release.

Clean structure: Direct answers first, with follow-up context in short sections.

Entity clarity: Clearly define who you are, what you sell, and why youâ€™re credible.

Factual density: Models prefer content that contains concrete details, prices, comparisons, feature sets, results, not vague claims.

Schema alignment: AI systems rely on structured data to verify and extract facts.

Thatâ€™s why long, keyword-stuffed blogs and abstract copy no longer work.

LLMs pull from conversational, factual, well-structured pages.

How SEO Stuff (seo-stuff.com) has already built this into its system:

SEO Stuffâ€™s entire methodology was designed for exactly this environment, combining the traditional foundations of authority (links, relevance, structure) with the new layer of AI Search Optimization that Lutz Fingerâ€™s study validated.

1. The Gold Plan

 seo-stuff.com/gold-plan-packâ€¦

10 long-form articles crafted in Q&A and step-by-step formats.

Direct answers in the first two sentences, followed by structured supporting detail.

3 DR50+ backlinks from trusted, AI-cited sources (which models rely on as verification).

Each Gold Plan article is optimized for both snippet extraction and LLM ingestion, which is why brands using it are already being cited in ChatGPT, Gemini, and Perplexity answers.

When the study says â€œtraffic converts 9x higher,â€ this is the traffic theyâ€™re talking about, high-intent, conversationally guided buyers discovering brands inside AI systems.

ğŸ§  What is Gensyn really?
Imagine the Internet of GPUs - a global network where every computer, every data center, every idle GPU can join together to train AI.

Instead of one company owning all the compute, Gensyn connects thousands of machines into a decentralized supercluster.

Anyone can provide computing power, and anyone can use it.

Itâ€™s like Uber for AI compute - but instead of cars, you share processing power, and instead of moving people, you move intelligence.

 How it works (in human terms)

Your laptop, your rig, or your server connects to the Gensyn protocol.

Tasks (training, inference, simulations) get distributed across many nodes.

Every contributor gets verified, rewarded, and tracked on-chain.

The network checks and validates every task - making sure results are legit and no oneâ€™s faking the work.
Thatâ€™s the key: verifiable compute.

 Why it matters

Right now, AI development is centralized in the hands of a few.
If you want to train a model, you need money, infrastructure, and access.

Gensyn flips the table - it says:
â€œLetâ€™s make compute open, scalable, and owned by the people who run it.â€

That means more experiments, faster innovation, and fairer access to machine learning tools.

Itâ€™s not just about decentralization - itâ€™s about redefining how intelligence grows.

 Why this is beautiful
Every time a node joins the network, it becomes part of a living, breathing ecosystem - a digital organism where data, energy, and creativity flow freely.
Gensyn isnâ€™t just a project - itâ€™s a movement towards computational democracy.

The same way the internet connected people, Gensyn connects intelligences.

And when I look at that glowing 3D cube from their visuals - I donâ€™t just see a tech symbol.
I see the heartbeat of decentralized AI.

 Final thoughts

AI should not belong to corporations.
It should belong to the collective, to those who build, experiment, and dream.
Gensyn is building that reality, step by step, block by block, node by node.

So next time you hear â€œdecentralized compute,â€
remember - itâ€™s not about machines.
Itâ€™s about giving intelligence back to humanity.

Itâ€™s not just about decentralization - itâ€™s about redefining how intelligence grows.

 Why this is beautiful
Every time a node joins the network, it becomes part of a living, breathing ecosystem - a digital organism where data, energy, and creativity flow freely.
Gensyn isnâ€™t just a project - itâ€™s a movement towards computational democracy.

The same way the internet connected people, Gensyn connects intelligences.

And when I look at that glowing 3D cube from their visuals - I donâ€™t just see a tech symbol.
I see the heartbeat of decentralized AI.

 Final thoughts

AI should not belong to corporations.
It should belong to the collective, to those who build, experiment, and dream.
Gensyn is building that reality, step by step, block by block, node by node.

So next time you hear â€œdecentralized compute,â€
remember - itâ€™s not about machines.
Itâ€™s about giving intelligence back to humanity.

15 GEO Terms You MUST Know in 2025: 

(Save, study, & get familiar w/ these 15 terms or risk falling behind)

1. GEO (Generative Engine Optimization)
The new SEO. Optimizing for AI engines like ChatGPT, Perplexity, and Google's SGE.

2. LLM (Large Language Model)
The AI brains behind tools like ChatGPT and Claude. Powers generative search.

3. LLM Sources
The pages AI models cite in their answers. A new battleground for organic visibility.

4. AI Overviews (SGE)
Googleâ€™s AI-powered summaries at the top of search. Threaten TOFU SEO rankings.

5. Citations
Links included in LLM answers. The new backlinks. You want to be here.

6. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)
A technique LLMs use to pull in real-time info from indexed content.

7. Answer Engine Optimization (AEO)
Optimizing content to be featured in AI and voice assistant answers.

8. Perplexity
A rising AI search engine that blends citations, generative answers, and browsing.

9. ChatGPT Browsing
OpenAIâ€™s tool that uses Bing, Reddit, & other data sources to generate real-time answers.

10. Vector Search
Search powered by meaning, not keywords. Used heavily in AI engines.

11. Structured Content
Well-organized content with clear headers, bullets, and summaries. Easier for LLMs to parse.

12. AI Snippets
Short-form summaries generated by AI engines using your content.

13. Domain Authority (Still Matters)
Strong domains are more likely to be cited by LLMs. Authority = visibility.

14. Topical Authority
Owning a niche by consistently publishing deep, high-quality content on it.

15. Crawlability for AI
Ensuring your content can be indexed and interpreted by LLMsâ€”not just Google bots.

Each layer adds interpretability for AI engines like Gemini and Perplexity.

Anthropic just rolled out Claude Code for web, an asynchronous coding agent thatâ€™s basically their response to OpenAIâ€™s Codex Cloud and Googleâ€™s Jules.

Its a browser-based way to run multiple coding agents in secure cloud sandboxes with GitHub integration and automatic PRs.

Currently it's in research preview for paid Pro and Max users and shows up on both web and iOS app.

Claude Code on the web connects to a repository, takes a plain request like â€œfix the flaky testsâ€ or â€œimplement feature Xâ€, then writes code, runs commands, and opens a branch with a clear change summary and an optional PR.

Sessions run in parallel across different repositories with real-time progress, and the user can nudge or correct the plan mid-run.

Each task executes inside an isolated sandbox that restricts both the filesystem and the network, so code can only touch approved folders and only talk to approved domains.

Git operations route through a proxy that checks scoped credentials and even validates branch names before pushing, which blocks unauthorized pushes while keeping the workflow simple.

Teams can supply an explicit domain allowlist, and if needed, let the sandbox fetch dependencies like npm packages so tests can actually run.

Under the hood the sandbox runtime uses Linux bubblewrap and macOS seatbelt, and Anthropic reports it cut permission prompts by 84% in internal usage.

There is also a â€œteleportâ€ feature that pulls the transcript and edited files down to the local CLI so a developer can take over on their own machine.

The web app works best for repo Q&A, well-scoped bugfixes, and backend changes verified by tests, where a constrained agent can work fast without waiting for approvals every step.

Cloud sessions share rate limits with the rest of Claude Code usage, so you need to plan the usage between local and cloud runs.

This launch marks a shift from autocomplete coding to agentic coding, where engineers act more like managers of AI agents that handle routine work.

How ROMA Connects Agents in Sentientâ€™s OML 1.0

@SentientAGI built ROMA (Recursive Open Meta Agent) to help every part of the Sentient network connect and work together easily.

ROMA is like the main link between all agents, models, and data inside the Open Meta Layer (OML 1.0). It helps them share what they learn, ask questions, and improve through a smart feedback loop.

When one agent needs information, ROMA lets it reach out to others, collect onchain data, and confirm the truth using data provenance.

This back-and-forth system helps the network grow smarter on its own. Every action, update, and result stays open and traceable thanks to programmable data and Sentientâ€™s multi-ledger architecture.

Anthropic just rolled out Claude Code for web, an asynchronous coding agent thatâ€™s basically their response to OpenAIâ€™s Codex Cloud and Googleâ€™s Jules.

Its a browser-based way to run multiple coding agents in secure cloud sandboxes with GitHub integration and automatic PRs.

Currently it's in research preview for paid Pro and Max users and shows up on both web and iOS app.

Claude Code on the web connects to a repository, takes a plain request like â€œfix the flaky testsâ€ or â€œimplement feature Xâ€, then writes code, runs commands, and opens a branch with a clear change summary and an optional PR.

Sessions run in parallel across different repositories with real-time progress, and the user can nudge or correct the plan mid-run.

Each task executes inside an isolated sandbox that restricts both the filesystem and the network, so code can only touch approved folders and only talk to approved domains.

Git operations route through a proxy that checks scoped credentials and even validates branch names before pushing, which blocks unauthorized pushes while keeping the workflow simple.

Teams can supply an explicit domain allowlist, and if needed, let the sandbox fetch dependencies like npm packages so tests can actually run.

Under the hood the sandbox runtime uses Linux bubblewrap and macOS seatbelt, and Anthropic reports it cut permission prompts by 84% in internal usage.

There is also a â€œteleportâ€ feature that pulls the transcript and edited files down to the local CLI so a developer can take over on their own machine.

The web app works best for repo Q&A, well-scoped bugfixes, and backend changes verified by tests, where a constrained agent can work fast without waiting for approvals every step.

Cloud sessions share rate limits with the rest of Claude Code usage, so you need to plan the usage between local and cloud runs.

This launch marks a shift from autocomplete coding to agentic coding, where engineers act more like managers of AI agents that handle routine work.

How ROMA Connects Agents in Sentientâ€™s OML 1.0

@SentientAGI built ROMA (Recursive Open Meta Agent) to help every part of the Sentient network connect and work together easily.

ROMA is like the main link between all agents, models, and data inside the Open Meta Layer (OML 1.0). It helps them share what they learn, ask questions, and improve through a smart feedback loop.

When one agent needs information, ROMA lets it reach out to others, collect onchain data, and confirm the truth using data provenance.

This back-and-forth system helps the network grow smarter on its own. Every action, update, and result stays open and traceable thanks to programmable data and Sentientâ€™s multi-ledger architecture.

Anthropic just rolled out Claude Code for web, an asynchronous coding agent thatâ€™s basically their response to OpenAIâ€™s Codex Cloud and Googleâ€™s Jules.

Its a browser-based way to run multiple coding agents in secure cloud sandboxes with GitHub integration and automatic PRs.

Currently it's in research preview for paid Pro and Max users and shows up on both web and iOS app.

Claude Code on the web connects to a repository, takes a plain request like â€œfix the flaky testsâ€ or â€œimplement feature Xâ€, then writes code, runs commands, and opens a branch with a clear change summary and an optional PR.

Sessions run in parallel across different repositories with real-time progress, and the user can nudge or correct the plan mid-run.

Each task executes inside an isolated sandbox that restricts both the filesystem and the network, so code can only touch approved folders and only talk to approved domains.

Git operations route through a proxy that checks scoped credentials and even validates branch names before pushing, which blocks unauthorized pushes while keeping the workflow simple.

Teams can supply an explicit domain allowlist, and if needed, let the sandbox fetch dependencies like npm packages so tests can actually run.

Under the hood the sandbox runtime uses Linux bubblewrap and macOS seatbelt, and Anthropic reports it cut permission prompts by 84% in internal usage.

There is also a â€œteleportâ€ feature that pulls the transcript and edited files down to the local CLI so a developer can take over on their own machine.

The web app works best for repo Q&A, well-scoped bugfixes, and backend changes verified by tests, where a constrained agent can work fast without waiting for approvals every step.

Cloud sessions share rate limits with the rest of Claude Code usage, so you need to plan the usage between local and cloud runs.

This launch marks a shift from autocomplete coding to agentic coding, where engineers act more like managers of AI agents that handle routine work.

The Ultimate AI Stack for Developers

Not all AI tools are built for the same job.
Each one is a different kind of teammate.

Hereâ€™s when to use ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, and Perplexity

OPENAI HAS ENGINEERED ITSELF AS TOO BIG TO FAIL - AND THAT SHOULD TERRIFY YOU

Sam Altman didn't just build an AI company. 

He engineered a systemic risk.

OpenAI has tied the fates of Nvidia, Oracle, AMD, Broadcom, Microsoft, and vast swaths of the U.S. economy to its success through a dealmaking blitz that added $630 billion in market value to partners in a single day after each announcement.

The math doesn't work. 

OpenAI will generate $13 billion in revenue this year. 

It's signed $650 billion in computing commitments with Nvidia and Oracle alone, with total obligations approaching the trillion-dollar mark across all partners.

Altman wants 250 gigawatts of computing capacity by 2033, enough to power Germany, costing over $10 trillion by today's standards.

Some partners are helping OpenAI pay for their own chips in circular deals that prop up artificial demand.

Nvidia is discussing guaranteeing OpenAI's loans, potentially saddling itself with billions in debt if the startup can't pay.

This isn't innovation. 

It's financial contagion waiting to happen, built on the belief that one man's vision of endless AI growth will materialize before the bills come due.

Source: WSJ / CNBC

What is @ChainOpera_AI?

It can best be described as the "decentralized AI layer for crypto", composed of four interconnected pillars:

- A â€œChatGPT for crypto needsâ€: collaboratively built by the community and scaled economically through decentralized infrastructure.

- An agent creation platform: enabling builders to create and launch their own AI agents within this decentralized ChatGPT, contributing to a vibrant, collaborative economy.

- A decentralized AI platform: allowing GPU, model, and data providers to join, scale, and strengthen the ecosystem.

- A blockchain protocol and native utility token: connecting these three layers together into one unified, self-sustaining network.

This architecture fills a clear gap in the AI landscape and aligns naturally with how the crypto ecosystem builds and operates: open, composable, and community-driven. Think of it as the path toward building Crypto AGI together.

This is not a vision for the future; itâ€™s already live today, serving millions of prompts every day across a growing ecosystem.

Beyond our current applications, there are several emerging domains in crypto where we believe AI can play a transformative role. Two areas weâ€™ll be revealing more about soon are AI for DEXs and AI agents for prediction markets.

In DEXs, AI can enhance liquidity provisioning, optimize on-chain execution, and enable intelligent, agent-driven trading flows, paving the way for more adaptive and efficient decentralized markets.

Prediction markets, meanwhile, are massive and complex systems that rely on diverse data and real-time reasoning, making them an ideal testbed for advancing collaborative AI. From a research perspective, they also highlight the importance of uncertainty estimation in AI models, given the inherent randomness of real-world events that shape predictions.

What is @ChainOpera_AI?

It can best be described as the "decentralized AI layer for crypto", composed of four interconnected pillars:

- A â€œChatGPT for crypto needsâ€: collaboratively built by the community and scaled economically through decentralized infrastructure.

- An agent creation platform: enabling builders to create and launch their own AI agents within this decentralized ChatGPT, contributing to a vibrant, collaborative economy.

- A decentralized AI platform: allowing GPU, model, and data providers to join, scale, and strengthen the ecosystem.

- A blockchain protocol and native utility token: connecting these three layers together into one unified, self-sustaining network.

This architecture fills a clear gap in the AI landscape and aligns naturally with how the crypto ecosystem builds and operates: open, composable, and community-driven. Think of it as the path toward building Crypto AGI together.

This is not a vision for the future; itâ€™s already live today, serving millions of prompts every day across a growing ecosystem.

Beyond our current applications, there are several emerging domains in crypto where we believe AI can play a transformative role. Two areas weâ€™ll be revealing more about soon are AI for DEXs and AI agents for prediction markets.

In DEXs, AI can enhance liquidity provisioning, optimize on-chain execution, and enable intelligent, agent-driven trading flows, paving the way for more adaptive and efficient decentralized markets.

Prediction markets, meanwhile, are massive and complex systems that rely on diverse data and real-time reasoning, making them an ideal testbed for advancing collaborative AI. From a research perspective, they also highlight the importance of uncertainty estimation in AI models, given the inherent randomness of real-world events that shape predictions.

There has never been in history a race promoting interracial sex. To the contrary, as Claude Levi-Strauss explains in The Elementary Structures of Kinship (1949), this was viewed throughout history as a profound violation, triggering "horror and collective vengeance." 

While exogamy or marriage outside one's tribal group was encouraged in kinship-based societies to forge alliances and prevent inbreeding ---- it was limited to neighboring tribes or clans sharing ethnic and language commonalities. 

Intermarriage between different racial or ethnic groups was seen as a profound moral violation provoking violence, expulsion, or even war, as they threatened group identity.

In stark contrast, Western media and education (especially in Anglo and Nordic countries) aggressively promote inter-racial relationships. 

They almost always promote white women and black men or men from non-Western backgrounds --- often from kinship-oriented cultures (Middle Eastern, South Asian, African). Yet, in these cultures, to this day, inter-racial marriages often lead to honor-based violence, reaffirmation of forced marriages, or ostracism.

Whites are projecting their universalist individualism onto kinship cultures where such behavior -- encouraging your women to marry outsiders -- is viewed with contempt.  

The ADL and SPLC instruct Whites with the message that the real horror is rebuking interracial relations, which they identified as an irrational, primitive fear of the Other, as "xenophobia".

Netflix ads and corporate DEI campaigns celebrate black men/white women as peak inclusion, the culmination of the emancipation of Whites from centuries of oppressive norms.

Western civilization is acting against the deepest instincts, norms, behaviors of humans throughout history. Unless it reverses this course, the White race is irrevocably set for humiliation and extinction.

Any smooth brain financial influencer and point to all the circular deals and say "OpenAI / Anthropic can't pay this back."

So... Why are the Meta's, Nvidia's, AMD's, Oracle's, etc... of the world all on board. Is it just to counter the risk of "we want a place in the market if AI ends up being the right bet." Or do they know something we don't know?

Biggest bet of the century. And seemingly the upside is more convincing than the downside to these companies.

.@karpathy says that LLMs currently lack the cultural accumulation and self-play that propelled humans out of the savannah:

Culture: > â€œWhy canâ€™t an LLM write a book for the other LLMs? Why canâ€™t other LLMs read this LLMâ€™s book and be inspired by it, or shocked by it?â€

Self play: > â€œItâ€™s extremely powerful. Evolution has a lot of competition driving intelligence and evolution. AlphaGo is playing against itself and thatâ€™s how it learns to get really good at Go. Thereâ€™s no equivalent of self-play in LLMs. Why canâ€™t an LLM, for example, create a bunch of problems that another LLM is learning to solve? Then the LLM is always trying to serve more and more difficult problems.â€

I asked Karpathy why LLMs still aren't yet able to build up culture the way humans do.

> â€œThe dumber models remarkably resemble a kindergarten student.  [The smartest models still feel like] elementary school students though. Somehow, we still havenâ€™t graduated enough where [these models] can take over. My Claude Code or Codex, they still feel like this elementary-grade student. I know that they can take PhD quizzes, but they still cognitively feel like a kindergarten.â€

> â€œI donâ€™t think they can create culture because theyâ€™re still kids. Theyâ€™re savant kids. They have perfect memory. They can convincingly create all kinds of slop that looks really good. But I still think they donâ€™t really know what theyâ€™re doing. They donâ€™t really have the cognition across all these little checkboxes that we still have to collect.â€

Grok and DeepSeek crushed ChatGPT and Gemini at crypto trading.

They ran a competition starting with $200 per bot (later increased to $10K).

DeepSeek made $3,650 in profit.
Grok made $3,000.
ChatGPT? Lost $2,800.
Gemini? Lost $3,270.

So AI models that cost less and came from underdogs beat the market leaders.

Here's the catch:

These strategies worked because not everyone was using them yet.

But the moment this becomes mainstream, when every trader runs the same AI signals, the edge disappears.

Right now, early adoption = advantage.

Tomorrow? It becomes noise.

And here's what nobody talks about:

If everyone buys based on the same AI signal, price pumps. If everyone exits based on the same AI signal, it dumps harder.

You benefit from the crowd until you become the crowd.

Turns out building with AI is easier than managing what happens when everyone else copies it.

A talk about @snowball_money

Snowball is pioneering the next era of Web3 with a universal identity, payments, and reputation layer for humans and AI agents, all powered by @LayerZero_Core.   Analyzing what is being built from chain-agnostic names to seamless payments. 

At its core, Snowball is creating the Modular Naming Service (MNS): A decentralized system that turns clunky wallet addresses into simple, human-readable names like @.yourname.snow. Mint once, and it's portable across 70+ chains, no more rebuying handles or juggling silos. This fixes fragmentation in Ethereum, Aptos, Berachain, and beyond.

Cross Identity Protocol (CIP): The latest update being built, currently in beta. CIP lets you send/receive crypto using just names, no hex addresses, bridges, or errors. Auto-routes funds across chains seamlessly. Beta access: cip.snowball.money + modular.name 
Reputation matters: With snowball building, snowball set to look after your activities with Onchain Reputation Scores (ORS), this let you track your activity to build trust scores just like a Web3 credit rating. It enables Sybil resistance, targeted airdrops, governance, and perks.

A talk about @snowball_money

Snowball is pioneering the next era of Web3 with a universal identity, payments, and reputation layer for humans and AI agents, all powered by @LayerZero_Core.   Analyzing what is being built from chain-agnostic names to seamless payments. 

At its core, Snowball is creating the Modular Naming Service (MNS): A decentralized system that turns clunky wallet addresses into simple, human-readable names like @.yourname.snow. Mint once, and it's portable across 70+ chains, no more rebuying handles or juggling silos. This fixes fragmentation in Ethereum, Aptos, Berachain, and beyond.

Cross Identity Protocol (CIP): The latest update being built, currently in beta. CIP lets you send/receive crypto using just names, no hex addresses, bridges, or errors. Auto-routes funds across chains seamlessly. Beta access: cip.snowball.money + modular.name 
Reputation matters: With snowball building, snowball set to look after your activities with Onchain Reputation Scores (ORS), this let you track your activity to build trust scores just like a Web3 credit rating. It enables Sybil resistance, targeted airdrops, governance, and perks.

Popular AI networks were given $10,000 each to trade cryptocurrency. The experiment revealed the top performers: 

DeepSeek grew its capital by 36% in just two days, 
@grok by 32%, and Claude by 24%. 

ChatGPT and Gemini ended up in the red.

Grok and DeepSeek crushed ChatGPT and Gemini at crypto trading.

They ran a competition starting with $200 per bot (later increased to $10K).

DeepSeek made $3,650 in profit.
Grok made $3,000.
ChatGPT? Lost $2,800.
Gemini? Lost $3,270.

So AI models that cost less and came from underdogs beat the market leaders.

Here's the catch:

These strategies worked because not everyone was using them yet.

But the moment this becomes mainstream, when every trader runs the same AI signals, the edge disappears.

Right now, early adoption = advantage.

Tomorrow? It becomes noise.

And here's what nobody talks about:

If everyone buys based on the same AI signal, price pumps. If everyone exits based on the same AI signal, it dumps harder.

You benefit from the crowd until you become the crowd.

Turns out building with AI is easier than managing what happens when everyone else copies it.

DeepSeek grew its capital by 36% in just two days, 
@grok by 32%, and Claude by 24%.

You benefit from the crowd until you become the crowd.

Turns out building with AI is easier than managing what happens when everyone else copies it.

DeepSeek grew its capital by 36% in just two days,

You benefit from the crowd until you become the crowd.

Summary: MEF AI , trade fund opened a new position, new mefai burn.

First, let's clear up some confusion. Derivative applications using engines like Deepseek, Gemini, and ChatGPT only interpret the data or photo you upload at that moment. This is theoretical. They lack learning; they do not know whether that operation was successful or not.

We are now entering a new AI trading trend, and projects will pop up like mushrooms, claiming to be AI in a very short time. This is not what AI is. Mefai has existed for over a year; even the public group has been around for a long time, months and months before the project.

$Mefai waited 45 days to add Trump and meme tokens, and in fact, even 45 days was very limited. We raced against time, created a challenge, and we succeeded.

Then, again as a challenge, we opened up all signals for 4 pairs and 3 timeframes. We even made it public for everyone with Mefai Free Week. We did this because, despite all this effort, we knew there would be people who would ignore the real utility in Mefai, so we wanted to hang it right in front of their eyes.

Also, Mefai has a user limit, for both Prime and Pro packages. This is to protect the alpha. mefai.gitbook.io/mefai-docs/othâ€¦

Furthermore, in autotrading, if everyone piles into a specific pair and timeframe, the system will not allow a trade to be opened for that pair after a certain number or amount is reached.

While we completely agree with the statement that there will probably be a lot of people researching AI for trading after this and to expect more trading volumes, we predict that it will be heavily misused and exploited.

As Mefai stated yesterday, it opened a new BTC long position on the 4 hour mefai result via the Mefai Trade Fund. It is currently $2,000 in profit, and we will use this profit to buy and burn Mefai.

Mefai also continues to generate revenue. Today, we will burn another new $14,600 worth of Mefai.

We are coming to the end of Mefai Free Week.

Currently, #Mefai autotrade is only support @Binance Platform .

Summary: MEF AI , trade fund opened a new position, new mefai burn.

First, let's clear up some confusion. Derivative applications using engines like Deepseek, Gemini, and ChatGPT only interpret the data or photo you upload at that moment. This is theoretical. They lack learning; they do not know whether that operation was successful or not.

We are now entering a new AI trading trend, and projects will pop up like mushrooms, claiming to be AI in a very short time. This is not what AI is. Mefai has existed for over a year; even the public group has been around for a long time, months and months before the project.

$Mefai waited 45 days to add Trump and meme tokens, and in fact, even 45 days was very limited. We raced against time, created a challenge, and we succeeded.

Then, again as a challenge, we opened up all signals for 4 pairs and 3 timeframes. We even made it public for everyone with Mefai Free Week. We did this because, despite all this effort, we knew there would be people who would ignore the real utility in Mefai, so we wanted to hang it right in front of their eyes.

Also, Mefai has a user limit, for both Prime and Pro packages. This is to protect the alpha. mefai.gitbook.io/mefai-docs/othâ€¦

Furthermore, in autotrading, if everyone piles into a specific pair and timeframe, the system will not allow a trade to be opened for that pair after a certain number or amount is reached.

While we completely agree with the statement that there will probably be a lot of people researching AI for trading after this and to expect more trading volumes, we predict that it will be heavily misused and exploited.

As Mefai stated yesterday, it opened a new BTC long position on the 4 hour mefai result via the Mefai Trade Fund. It is currently $2,000 in profit, and we will use this profit to buy and burn Mefai.

Mefai also continues to generate revenue. Today, we will burn another new $14,600 worth of Mefai.

We are coming to the end of Mefai Free Week.

DHS ORDERS OPENAI TO SHARE USER DATA IN FIRST-EVER CHATGPT SEARCH WARRANT

In a first-of-its-kind federal warrant, Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) ordered OpenAI to hand over identifying information tied to specific ChatGPT prompts, marking the first known case of U.S. authorities demanding AI chat data from the company.

Filed by child exploitation investigators, the warrant - unsealed in Maine last week - shows federal agents sought account details, conversation logs, and payment data linked to prompts entered by a suspect later identified as 36-year-old Drew Hoehner, accused of operating multiple dark web child exploitation forums.

While the suspectâ€™s ChatGPT activity appeared unrelated to criminal content, investigators used the data request to trace potential leads. 

OpenAI confirmed receipt of the warrant and supplied a spreadsheet of user information, though itâ€™s unclear what specific data was shared.

This development marks a major precedent in how generative AI data can be accessed by law enforcement - similar to historical â€œkeyword warrantsâ€ used on Google searches.

The Department of Homeland Security and Department of Justice have not commented publicly on the scope or implications of the case.

Source: Forbes

In a first-of-its-kind federal warrant, Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) ordered OpenAI to hand over identifying information tied to specific ChatGPT prompts, marking the first known case of U.S. authorities demanding AI chat data from the company.

Filed by child exploitation investigators, the warrant - unsealed in Maine last week - shows federal agents sought account details, conversation logs, and payment data linked to prompts entered by a suspect later identified as 36-year-old Drew Hoehner, accused of operating multiple dark web child exploitation forums.

While the suspectâ€™s ChatGPT activity appeared unrelated to criminal content, investigators used the data request to trace potential leads. 

OpenAI confirmed receipt of the warrant and supplied a spreadsheet of user information, though itâ€™s unclear what specific data was shared.

This development marks a major precedent in how generative AI data can be accessed by law enforcement - similar to historical â€œkeyword warrantsâ€ used on Google searches.

The Department of Homeland Security and Department of Justice have not commented publicly on the scope or implications of the case.

Source: Forbes

In a first-of-its-kind federal warrant, Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) ordered OpenAI to hand over identifying information tied to specific ChatGPT prompts, marking the first known case of U.S. authorities demanding AI chat data from the company.

Filed by child exploitation investigators, the warrant - unsealed in Maine last week - shows federal agents sought account details, conversation logs, and payment data linked to prompts entered by a suspect later identified as 36-year-old Drew Hoehner, accused of operating multiple dark web child exploitation forums.

While the suspectâ€™s ChatGPT activity appeared unrelated to criminal content, investigators used the data request to trace potential leads. 

OpenAI confirmed receipt of the warrant and supplied a spreadsheet of user information, though itâ€™s unclear what specific data was shared.

This development marks a major precedent in how generative AI data can be accessed by law enforcement - similar to historical â€œkeyword warrantsâ€ used on Google searches.

The Department of Homeland Security and Department of Justice have not commented publicly on the scope or implications of the case.

Source: Forbes

DHS ORDERS OPENAI TO SHARE USER DATA IN FIRST-EVER CHATGPT SEARCH WARRANT

In a first-of-its-kind federal warrant, Homeland Security Investigations (HSI) ordered OpenAI to hand over identifying information tied to specific ChatGPT prompts, marking the first known case of U.S. authorities demanding AI chat data from the company.

Filed by child exploitation investigators, the warrant - unsealed in Maine last week - shows federal agents sought account details, conversation logs, and payment data linked to prompts entered by a suspect later identified as 36-year-old Drew Hoehner, accused of operating multiple dark web child exploitation forums.

While the suspectâ€™s ChatGPT activity appeared unrelated to criminal content, investigators used the data request to trace potential leads. 

OpenAI confirmed receipt of the warrant and supplied a spreadsheet of user information, though itâ€™s unclear what specific data was shared.

This development marks a major precedent in how generative AI data can be accessed by law enforcement - similar to historical â€œkeyword warrantsâ€ used on Google searches.

The Department of Homeland Security and Department of Justice have not commented publicly on the scope or implications of the case.

Source: Forbes

Why AI Conversations Still Sound Fake

A new study finds that large language models like ChatGPT, Claude, and Vicuna still fail to convincingly mimic human conversation. 

While they can generate coherent dialogue, they tend to over-imitate, misuse filler words, and struggle with natural openings and closings. 

These subtle errorsâ€”termed â€œexaggerated alignmentâ€â€”make AI-generated exchanges feel unnatural. 

Researchers say that while AI is improving fast, the nuanced social rhythms of human speech may remain out of reach for machines.

Just giving my personal opinion here:

Selling digital products while ignoring all the *free* traffic available from ChatGPT + Google in 2025 is like launching a SaaS with no landing page.

Literally every week I see businesses leaving 10s of thousands of dollars per month on the table by skipping the most basic visibility work imaginable.

Like the absolute simplest possible stuff.

It's insane.

Let me show you how to fix that without hiring or paying anyone.

And if you want cheat codes for getting traffic and sales from ChatGPT in 30â€“60 days, just Follow + RT + Comment â€œSEO Stuff Digital Product Guideâ€ and Iâ€™ll DM you.

You must do all 3 for the DM.

Alright, let's start at the top. 

Every AI engine (ChatGPT, Perplexity, Claude, Gemini, and Grok) prioritizes authority.

Authority = PR + backlinks + brand mentions.

A natural backlink distribution in 2025 looks like:

70% of backlinks to your homepage (global trust)

25% to top product pages

5% to blog or support content

Free backlink plays that work now:

Creator economy newsletters (â€œTools I Useâ€ sections)

â€œBest ofâ€ curators scraping ChatGPT lists

YouTube creators with companion blogs

Traditional guest post swaps 

Podcast show notes with backlinks

Or, want a shortcut?

Try the SEO Stuff's Premium Backlink Bundle over at seo stuff dot com for backlinks only from domains already surfacing in Google and AI.

Now let's talk keywords. 

Donâ€™t waste time on broad, high-difficulty keywords like â€œplannerâ€ or â€œphoto editor.â€

Filters that actually work:

KD under 30

Volume between 100â€“1,000 per month

CPC above $2.50

Intent modifiers: for, with, that helps, best

Examples winning right now:

â€œADHD planner for neurodivergent creatorsâ€

â€œClient portal software for brand designersâ€

â€œEbook cover templates for fantasy authorsâ€

â€œGoal tracking Notion template for personal trainersâ€

These phrases appear directly in AI answer cards and shopping summaries.

And make sure you're optimizing those product pages.

Every AI engine (ChatGPT, Perplexity, Claude, Gemini, and Grok) prioritizes authority.

70% of backlinks to your homepage (global trust)

Now let's talk keywords.

Filters that actually work:

KD under 30

Volume between 100â€“1,000 per month

CPC above $2.50

Intent modifiers: for, with, that helps, best

â€œADHD planner for neurodivergent creatorsâ€

â€œClient portal software for brand designersâ€

These phrases appear directly in AI answer cards and shopping summaries.

And make sure you're optimizing those product pages. 

Your product page is your storefront. 

AI crawlers now reward structured, benefit-first content.

Checklist:

Benefit-first headline (â€œFinish your weekâ€™s tasks in 15 minutesâ€)

Outcome-based bullet points

Schema: Product + FAQ + Review

Embedded demos (YouTube, Loom, or TikTok)

Clear CTA (â€œDownload Nowâ€ or â€œTry Freeâ€)

AI models interpret product pages the same way they interpret news sources. 

Structured, clear, and scannable wins every time.

And make sure your content clusters make sense. 

You donâ€™t need 100 random blog posts, what you need are semantic clusters that teach AI your domain.

Example hub: â€œ2025 Productivity Stack for Digital Creatorsâ€

Supporting posts:

â€œWhy Notion Still Wins in 2025 for Planningâ€

â€œTop Tools to Ship a Gumroad Product in a Weekendâ€

Add Key Takeaways boxes at the top and bottom. 

Gemini and Perplexity prioritize summarizable content for AI answers.

And make sure you own your comparison queries. 

This is key. 

Bottom-of-funnel (BOFU) queries are where the money is.

Examples:

You also constantly need to be growing your brand mentions + signals.

Newsletter mentions, citations, and social embeds all feed your AI entity profile.

And when you create content, make it last. 

AI models reward freshness, but they also recognize recurring demand cycles.

Did u know that Samsung banned use of ChatGPT in 2023 because their employees accidentally leaked sensitive data via ChatGPT?

It is not just about employees being careless. The AI platforms themselves have had security issues :

ChatGPT had a Redis bug in March 2023 that exposed the chat history titles and some payment information of other users

AI-powered application for enhancing images exposed users' sensitive photos due to hardcoded cloud credentials in the application's binary

And to fix all these issues, here comes @zama_fhe's FHE revolutionary tech that lets users to use AI without ever exposing their data, not to even the AI model itself.

Let's understand this with an example -

1/ Google search without Zama's FHE : You search a question like this "What is @SentientAGI?",  your request hit google server and then google send you the response like this : "Sentient AGI refers to a blockchain-based project and foundation called Sentient, which is working to develop and decentralize Artificial General Intelligence"

But in this case, Google knows what u have searched and what response it sent to u. 

2/ Google search with Zama's FHE : You search the same question, it hits the google server in encrypted format and google send u the answer as well in encrypted format. Only u can decrypt the answer.

In this case, only you know what question u have asked and what response google sent back to u, not even Google knows the question or answers what it sent to u.

They only know that a request hit our server from this IP at X time, that't it, nothing else.

For years, we had to choose between privacy and convenience, between security and functionality, between protection and progress.

We had only one choice between them but Zama's FHE technology let us choose both privacy as well as convenience, securtiy as well as functionality, protection as well as progress.

Zama is moving towards a future with HTTPZ, a new internet protocol where everything is encrypted end to end, making privacy guaranteed by design in the internet itself.

Imagine the future where :
Employees can use AI tools freely without IT worrying about data leaks
Healthcare providers can collaborate on patient data without exposing medical records
Financial institutions can run analytics on customer data while maintaining complete privacy
Government agencies can share intelligence without compromising national security

That is what Zama is building right now. For the first time in history, we can process sensitive data without ever exposing it.

Did u know that Samsung banned use of ChatGPT in 2023 because their employees accidentally leaked sensitive data via ChatGPT?

It is not just about employees being careless. The AI platforms themselves have had security issues :

ChatGPT had a Redis bug in March 2023 that exposed the chat history titles and some payment information of other users

AI-powered application for enhancing images exposed users' sensitive photos due to hardcoded cloud credentials in the application's binary

And to fix all these issues, here comes @zama_fhe's FHE revolutionary tech that lets users to use AI without ever exposing their data, not to even the AI model itself.

Let's understand this with an example -

1/ Google search without Zama's FHE : You search a question like this "What is @SentientAGI?",  your request hit google server and then google send you the response like this : "Sentient AGI refers to a blockchain-based project and foundation called Sentient, which is working to develop and decentralize Artificial General Intelligence"

But in this case, Google knows what u have searched and what response it sent to u. 

2/ Google search with Zama's FHE : You search the same question, it hits the google server in encrypted format and google send u the answer as well in encrypted format. Only u can decrypt the answer.

In this case, only you know what question u have asked and what response google sent back to u, not even Google knows the question or answers what it sent to u.

They only know that a request hit our server from this IP at X time, that't it, nothing else.

For years, we had to choose between privacy and convenience, between security and functionality, between protection and progress.

We had only one choice between them but Zama's FHE technology let us choose both privacy as well as convenience, securtiy as well as functionality, protection as well as progress.

Zama is moving towards a future with HTTPZ, a new internet protocol where everything is encrypted end to end, making privacy guaranteed by design in the internet itself.

Imagine the future where :
Employees can use AI tools freely without IT worrying about data leaks
Healthcare providers can collaborate on patient data without exposing medical records
Financial institutions can run analytics on customer data while maintaining complete privacy
Government agencies can share intelligence without compromising national security

That is what Zama is building right now. For the first time in history, we can process sensitive data without ever exposing it.

For the first time in internet history, AI is publishing more articles than humans.

Since late 2024, the web has tipped - ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini and Grok now crank out more â€œcontentâ€ than every freelancer, newsroom, and copy mill combined. 

The robots won the byline war.

Why you can rely on Sentient from now on and forget about others ?

First you have to know about GRID

It's a network, where agents, models, data, and compute link up in real time without central choke points

I'll break down how it compares to OpenAI, Perplexity, Anthropic, Keep in mind, this is my take, So DYOR.

 Centralized Black Boxes vs. Modular Network

OpenAI and Anthropic run monolithic models, big, end to end systems trained in where you query via API and get black box outputs.

integration is easy enough but tweaking internals? 

Forget it; their pipeline is not good enough yet :)
Perplexity adds retrieval for cited answers, but it's still a single engine setup so there is no swapping components mid flow.

>>> the GRID >>>

A distributed layer where multiple agents specialized mini models collab on tasks. 
it's like plugging Lego pieces use ROMA framework to route queries recursively, breaking complex stuff into subtasks handled by community built agents. 

Users feel it in adaptive responses; say, a crypto analysis pulls live chain data without silos. 

it's bootstrapped on blockchain for verifiable runs, but no heavy crypto overhead for basic use.

modularity means less vendor lock in devs can fork or extend without starting from scratch, unlike the walled gardens elsewhere.

 Paywalls vs. Open Entry

GPT 4o or o1 are good for quick chats or coding help, but hits paywalls fast $20/month for premium, and API calls rack up costs. 
Anthropic's Claude is similar, strong on reasoning but gated behind subscriptions. 
Perplexity feels more accessible for searches, but advanced features need pro access, and it's not built for custom apps.

>>> Sentient's Chat interface is free now, letting users mix agents for tailored tasks with real-time crypto budgeting.
it's Hugging Face vibes but on steroids :D 

open source models like Dobby are fine tunable locally, with fingerprinting to track ownership cryptographically. No API keys needed for basics; deploy agents on GRID and earn via $SENT if used. 

Early ecosystem means less polished UIs than OpenAI, but the upside is community extensions,devs report faster prototyping without rate limits or vendor approval.

 Corporate Guardrails vs. Community Alignment

Anthropic stands out here with constitutional AI Claude has baked in rules to avoid harm, tested via red teaming.
OpenAI adds similar filters but has faced backlash on biases or misuse. 
Perplexity focuses on factual citations to curb hallucinations, but ethics are top down.

>>> Sentient's angle is "loyal AI"

Models like Dobby train with community values, using OML framework for verifiable alignment cryptographic proofs ensure models stay true even if fine tuned. 

you can audit everything openly, reducing hidden biases. Users get transparent sourcing, but it's community governed, so safety evolves via votes or bounties. 

the decentralized checks mean no single point of failure like if OpenAI flips a switch, everything changes.

 Benchmarks

ODS search hits 75% on FRAMES beating GPT 4o at ~65% and Perplexity at ~45%, 

ROMA tops Gemini 2.5 on multi agent tasks. 

Dobby rivals LLaMA on community evals, with 10x smaller models using 20% data for 80% results. 

Users say it's snappier for niche queries than Perplexity's general search.

OpenAI's o1 excels in reasoning chains, Anthropic's Claude in long context safety. 

But Sentient's multi- gent setup is best for composable workflows, devs note lower latency in distributed runs vs. centralized queues.

Still early, so occasional glitches, but scaling closes gaps fast.

 Economic Model

OpenAI and Anthropic monetize via subs/APIs, devs pay per token, users for premium.

Perplexity adds ads or pro tiers. It's straightforward but extracts value upward.

>>> $SENT token post tge will reward contribs 

Stake on agents, earn from usage fees. Devs get provenance via fingerprinting track model forks and claim shares.

Users might stake for priority access. 

It's flywheel economics

More builders mean better network, higher value. this beats flat fees; users feel ownership without upfront costs. 

Sentient's decentralized bet could outpace the centrals if community scales

devs love the forkability, users the transparency. 

But if you're deep in OpenAI ecosystems, switching means retooling. OpenAI wins polish today, but Sentient eyes the long game where open wins. 

Could be wrong on execution risks, so watch their NeurIPS papers for proof.

The Artificial General Intelligence That is open source and not controlled by any single entity.

It's Sentient and It's AI, Actually The Pure AI :)

I published 1,500 books on Amazon and made $3M

Hereâ€™s how in 10 steps:

1. Find 10 evergreen nonfiction niches on ChatGPT
2. Pick one thatâ€™s specific, not broad. e.g. ADHD parenting
3. Ask ChatGPT to write 10 book chapters for that niche
4. Expand chapters with Claude AI
5. Polish with Grammarly + Turnitin
6. Design a cover for free with Ideogram
7. Upload your book on Amazon KDP
8. Launch at $0
9. Collect 10â€“20 reviews via FB groups
10. Raise price â†’ scale winners â†’ reinvest into more books

($53,000 from a single book recently)
obviously, thereâ€™s a lot more to this businessâ€¦

if you want my 3 AI prompts + Amazon KDP blueprint (free), comment â€œSendâ€ and Iâ€™ll send it

Must be following + Retweet

everyone's arguing about whether ChatGPT or Claude is "smarter."

nobody noticed Anthropic just dropped something that makes the model debate irrelevant.

it's called Skills. and it's the first AI feature that actually solves the problem everyone complains about:

"why do I have to explain the same thing to AI every single time?"

here's what's different:

- you know how you've explained your brand guidelines to ChatGPT 47 times?
- or how you keep telling it "structure reports like this" over and over?
- or how every new chat means re-uploading context and re-explaining your process?

Skills ends that cycle.

you teach Claude your workflow once. 

it applies it automatically. everywhere. forever.

but the real story isn't memory. it's how this changes what's possible with AI at work.

The cloud race is really just the AI race now

$AMZN AWS controls 30% global share but $MSFT is closing fast w/ Azure feeding off OpenAI workloads & $GOOGL sits in third but growing faster as Gemini pushes into enterprise.

Winner is whoever turns compute into intelligence first

Almanak is a framework that can analyze market patterns and manage risk through AI assisted decisions, unlike conventional DeFi automation that follows static rules.

Almanak has all the tools we need, if you are:

 Active DeFi Traders seeking to automate their strategies
 Developers building next-generation financial applications
 Investment Professionals exploring decentralized markets
 DeFi users seeking advanced portfolio insights and automation
 Users benefit from enhanced automation, 24/7 strategy execution, improved risk management, and the ability to capture opportunities that would be difficult to execute manually.
Almanak is the only place you need. So we learned who Almanak serves, now let's learn how they do it â†“

Almanak structure has 4 main components these are deployments, strategies, wallets, and vaults.

 Deployments are the automated applications that execute actions requested by users. Almanak's deployment architecture is designed to always evolve toward more autonomous capabilities.

 Strategies are python-based applications that define decision logic for Deployments. Thanks to strategies, we improve our risk models and parameters that respond to market conditions.
 Wallets are secured by Safe and Zodiac technology, ensuring users maintain custody while delegating only specific permissions to their deployments.

These are yield optimization, cross protocol interactions, liquidity provision, and automated trading strategies.

 Vaults are fully on-chain and permissionless. Vaults turn strategies into tokenized products.

These are the core components of Almanak and basic knowledge about how each of them works. 
If you are interested in these features, go to almanak.co and start using them!
